title: Bankruptcy no barrier for owner of Caulfield Guineas hope
text:
Endresz borrowed his horse’s name from the world of poker; it describes the stuff coursing through the veins of the toughest customers.

“If you have this alligator blood, you are tenacious and you are resilient. And the objective is to never give up,” Endresz says.

He says the name has plenty of significance for what will surely be the most-colourful team behind any horse that saddles up for the Guineas on Saturday.

First there’s trainer David Vandyke, who overcame a heroin addiction early in his life to become one of Queensland’s canniest horsemen.

Trainer David Vandyke (L) and Allan Endresz (R) with Alligator Blood. Arsineh Houspian

Then there’s jockey Ryan Maloney, who has been open about his struggles with depression.

But Endresz is something else – a racing identity so colourful you need sunglasses just to read his name in the form guide.

Previously convicted of market manipulation, twice declared bankrupt and currently banned as a director by the corporate regulator until 2021, Endresz has been engaged in decades of furious litigation against the government.

Advertisement

Most of the cases trace back to the embezzlement of $8.73 million of taxpayer funds by a government consultant in 1998. Some of the funds were transferred to a company associated with Endresz, but he has long denied knowing the funds were embezzled, and was cleared of bribing the consultant.

Ryan Maloney rides Alligator Blood to victory in the the Caulfield Guineas Prelude. AAP

But an attempt by the government to recover that sum by freezing millions of dollars of Endresz’ assets – including, remarkably, the Illawarra Falcons NBL basketball team – clearly still burns.

He is currently waiting on the judgment on his latest legal battle, an appeal against his bankruptcy.

If Endresz wins that case – and he has no doubt that he’ll come out victorious, declaring there’s “no way the three judges will get out of the appeal points in my favour” – then he can pursue his ultimate goal of relaunching a failed $4.3 billion claim against the government for compensation.

“We’ll get it all back,” say Endresz, claiming parallels between his legal fight and the debut win of Alligator Blood. “That reminded me of how far back I was in the court cases.”

If you’re wondering how a bankrupt and banned director can own a horse that recently attracted an offer of $2.2 million, then Endresz has a quick answer.

The horse, like all of his assets, is owned through trusts. His affairs are specifically structured so assets can’t be got at by the courts.

Advertisement

“You’d have rocks in your heads if you ever put assets in your own name,” Endresz says cheerfully.

While he insists that a loss for Alligator Blood in the Guineas won’t derail a promising career, Endresz acknowledges having backed the horse at odds of 200-to-one.

“I’ve dreamed of horses and glory like this.”

Another punter cheering along with Endresz will be billionaire retailer and horseman Gerry Harvey, who bred Alligator Blood and owns its sire, All Too Hard.

Harvey’s stallion won the Guineas in 2012; if Alligator Blood can win on Saturday it will be All Too Hard’s first group one winner as a sire.
description: Twice-declared bankrupt and banned as a director until 2021, Allan Endresz somehow owns one of the top chances in the Caulfield Guineas.
